subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: Thank you, Moira, for pointing out what Mr. Read actually intended for QS.  I have been arguing against this idea that QS needs to be standardized ever since I
messageBody:
Thank you, Moira, for pointing out what Mr. Read actually intended for QS.  I have been arguing against this idea that QS needs to be standardized ever since I started this group.  People keep writing that we must have standardized spelling.  I guess this is a hangover from what they've been taught all their lives with Trad. Orth.  People don't seem to realize that a rigid standardization of spelling in QS just sets us back on the road that got TO in such a mess to begin with.

Paige

On 4/17/2013 2:56 PM, moira_ob wrote:
 

"As you're starting to notice, there is some individual variation in usage here.
Kingsley Read intended for Quikscript to have standard spelling regardless of
dialect. "

I have to disagree with you here. I met with Kingsley Read on a couple of occasions and I corresponded with him for over two years in the mid 60's in a group which consisted of a Northern irishman, a southern Englishman, Kingsley Read and myself. The whole point of Quikscript is that it is capable of reflecting local ways of speaking - be it American, Australian, Standard English or whatever. It is a phonetic alphabet and that assumes that it will be written as it is spoken.

The abbreviations in Senior QS are the only things that are standardised and they mostly ignore vowels.

Moira

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "guanolto" <scott@...> wrote:
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "stratocat6969" <john-bergsma@> wrote:
> > Thanks for your reply. Seeing as my writing will likely never see the light of day, I may take similar liberties with the ending half-t as you have.
> > The file I was referring to is: keybd_read.pdf, and it is in the fonts folder. It turns out I needed to reread the QSM, which answered my question 2). I'm still puzzled about the upper case W however. I might assume that it is supposed to sound like (pardon my attempt at expressing these sounds in a non-standard way) the first syllable of "yuppie", but it would seem to me that Mr. Read would have advised the combination #17 and #36. Your thoughts?
> /That's odd: That was exactly the file I had thought you were referring to, but on it I don't see any Quikscript letters. Anyway, if it's the same layout as used for the King Plus font, then at the uppercase W it would be the ligature of letters 26 and 36, intended for use in places like the last two sounds of the word "India."
>
> /As you're starting to notice, there is some individual variation in usage here. Kingsley Read intended for Quikscript to have standard spelling regardless of dialect. But as an American, I've come to see that such standardization results in a mass of illogical spellings for most users, ironically something which Quikscript was supposed to eliminate. For that reason, I've joined those who use QS according to their own pronunciation -- so I always use the letters "27-36" instead of that ligature you're mentioning. And "yuppie" would always be "17-36" just as you suggest, regardless.
>
> /As to speed of usage, I often wonder that myself: I've been using QS for about half a year, and I use it pretty fluidly, most of the time, though still not as fast as the standard Roman alphabet. I can still stare in the direction of a QS text and the meaning doesn't jump out at me as quickly and inavoidably as it does with orthodox writing. All the best to you with QS.
>
> Kind Regards,
>
> Scott
>



-- 
“Socialism is a philosophy of failure, the creed of ignorance, and the gospel of envy, its inherent virtue is the equal sharing of misery.” — Winston Churchill

Thank you, Moira, for pointing out what Mr. Read actually intended for 
QS.  I have been arguing against this idea that QS needs to be 
standardized ever since I started this group.  People keep writing that 
we must have standardized spelling.  I guess this is a hangover from 
what they've been taught all their lives with Trad. Orth.  People don't 
seem to realize that a rigid standardization of spelling in QS just sets 
us back on the road that got TO in such a mess to begin with.

Paige

On 4/17/2013 2:56 PM, moira_ob wrote:
>
> "As you're starting to notice, there is some individual variation in 
> usage here.
> Kingsley Read intended for Quikscript to have standard spelling 
> regardless of
> dialect. "
>
> I have to disagree with you here. I met with Kingsley Read on a couple 
> of occasions and I corresponded with him for over two years in the mid 
> 60's in a group which consisted of a Northern irishman, a southern 
> Englishman, Kingsley Read and myself. The whole point of Quikscript is 
> that it is capable of reflecting local ways of speaking - be it 
> American, Australian, Standard English or whatever. It is a phonetic 
> alphabet and that assumes that it will be written as it is spoken.
>
> The abbreviations in Senior QS are the only things that are 
> standardised and they mostly ignore vowels.
>
> Moira
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com 
> <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, "guanolto" <scott@...> wrote:
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com 
> <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, "stratocat6969" 
> <john-bergsma@> wrote:

> as you have.
> > > The file I was referring to is: keybd_read.pdf, and it is in the 
> fonts folder. It turns out I needed to reread the QSM, which answered 
> my question 2). I'm still puzzled about the upper case W however. I 
> might assume that it is supposed to sound like (pardon my attempt at 
> expressing these sounds in a non-standard way) the first syllable of 
> "yuppie", but it would seem to me that Mr. Read would have advised the 
> combination #17 and #36. Your thoughts?
> > /That's odd: That was exactly the file I had thought you were 
> referring to, but on it I don't see any Quikscript letters. Anyway, if 
> it's the same layout as used for the King Plus font, then at the 
> uppercase W it would be the ligature of letters 26 and 36, intended 
> for use in places like the last two sounds of the word "India."
> >
> > /As you're starting to notice, there is some individual variation in 
> usage here. Kingsley Read intended for Quikscript to have standard 
> spelling regardless of dialect. But as an American, I've come to see 
> that such standardization results in a mass of illogical spellings for 
> most users, ironically something which Quikscript was supposed to 
> eliminate. For that reason, I've joined those who use QS according to 
> their own pronunciation -- so I always use the letters "27-36" instead 
> of that ligature you're mentioning. And "yuppie" would always be 
> "17-36" just as you suggest, regardless.
> >
> > /As to speed of usage, I often wonder that myself: I've been using 
> QS for about half a year, and I use it pretty fluidly, most of the 
> time, though still not as fast as the standard Roman alphabet. I can 
> still stare in the direction of a QS text and the meaning doesn't jump 
> out at me as quickly and inavoidably as it does with orthodox writing. 
> All the best to you with QS.
> >
> > Kind Regards,
> >
> > Scott
> >
>
>
